newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela pay deal need not boost inflation - Casas.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela pay deal need not boost inflation - Casas.

text.p: Venezuelan inflation need not rise on recent public sector pay deals, Central Bank President Antonio Casas Gonzalez said -- it all depends on how the pay rises are financed.

"Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff has said inflation this year could reach 35 percent, but that's a very approximate measure," Casas told a congressional committee. "We still don't know how much the pay rises will finally be, nor, just as importantly, how they will be financed."

Casas was speaking to a committee studying the question of wages and bonus payments for public sector workers. The government announced last week an improved 35 percent pay rise offer and a 50 percent increase in bonus payments for the sector.

Central Bank director Domingo Maza Zavala, also present, stressed that in a recession-bound economy such as Venezuela's that has considerable idle capacity, the pay increases need not be inflationary.
"On the other hand, if the pay rises are too great, nominal wage gains will be eroded by inflation. One has to find a point of equilibrium," he said.

Casas earlier said average inflation for the year would be between 40 and 50 percent. Average inflation is a little-used measure that averages annualized inflation rates extrapolated from monthly inflation rates.
"The official inflation target for the year remains 25 percent," Casas said.
"The crux of the matter is not controlling pay rises, but how those rises will be financed," he added.
